item.title: Nibbles HackTheBox - Write-Up
item.description: This writeup will demonstrate my approach for pwning/rooting the HackTheBox machine called Nibbles to obtain the user & root flags. It is is considered to be an easy machine and suitable for beginners.

item.title: Jerry HackTheBox - Write-Up
item.description: This writeup will be my approach for pwning/rooting the HackTheBox machine called Jerry to obtain the user & root flags. It is considered to be an easy machine and suitable for beginners.

item.title: Devel HackTheBox - Write-Up
item.description: The first three ‘HackTheBox’ writeups in this blog demonstrated my approach for gaining root access to a target system with and without Metasploit. However, after pwning Devel I felt it was unnecessary to use Metasploit.

item.title: Blue HackTheBox - Write-Up
item.description: This blog piece details my approach for pwning the HackTheBox machine called Blue. As per usual for my HackTheBox writeups, I will try to pwn Blue with and without Metasploit.

item.title: Lame HackTheBox - Write-Up
item.description: This writeup will be my approach for pwning the HackTheBox machine called ‘Lame’ and how I have learned new things along the way. The writeup will be in two sections - with and without Metasploit.

item.title: Legacy HackTheBox - Write-Up
item.description: The HackTheBox machine Legacy represents the start of my journey into the field of ethical hacking. As I progress through these pieces I will explain my approach through each of the phases of a pen test.

item.title: Anomali Detect 2019 - 'Guardians of the Cyberverse'
item.description: My conference speaking experience During my placement/internship year I worked for the threat intelligence company Anomali as part of the Anomali Threat Research (ATR) team. I was offered the opportunity to speak at the company’s annual conference DETECT.

item.title: Raspberry Pi - 'Picade'
item.description: Building my own Raspberry Pi based table top games arcade - the ‘Picade’ When I heard that Nintendo was releasing the NES Classic Edition, it sounded somewhat nostalgic. The simplicity of the games and the ease with which they could be played sounded appealing.
